questions.text: Animal with a shell
Animals look like snails or limpets.
Order level ID Gastropoda.

outcome.name: gastropods
outcome.habitat: Wetlands / rivers.
outcome.description: To quote T. Sloane, booger with a crash helmet.

questions.text: Keep going.
Snails with flat shells.

outcome.name: Planorbidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands / Rivers, temporary waters.
outcome.movement: Slow, will retract into shell and drop off vegetation, so it is sometimes worth panning through sand at the end of a live pick to see if you can find them.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, really distinctive. Etymology: 'plan'-flat + 'orbi'-circle.

questions.text: Shells are not flat, have normal spire.
Snails are coiled, small (less than 10mm), often black or dark brown and occur in large numbers.

outcome.name: Potamopyrgus antipodarum
outcome.habitat: In very large numbers in impacted, high nutrient streams. INTRODUCED SPECIES (from New Zealand)
outcome.confusedWith: Some snails from the same family in healthy streams, see Genus Beddomeia, family Hydrobiidae, at the end of this section.
outcome.description: The shells of these snails vary considerably.  Some are smooth, while others develop pegs or teeth on the edges of the whorls.

questions.text: Snails not as above.
Shell sinistral (left handed - or footed)
Mottled pattern visible through the shell. You might need good light to see this

outcome.name: Physa acuta
outcome.habitat: Flowing water or wetlands widespread. INTRODUCED SPECIES (from the USA)
outcome.confusedWith: Planorbids can look very similar, but Physa acuta has a mottled mantle that is usually visible through the shell.

questions.text: Snail without obvious mottling.

outcome.name: Planorbids
outcome.habitat: Wetlands / rivers with slow water and lots of water plants. Common and diverse.
outcome.confusedWith: Algae covered shells might be difficult to distinguish from Physa acuta. These Snails are fairly diverse, so they might not look exactly the same as those in the picture; some have ornamentation or flattened tops.

questions.text: Shell dextral (right handed)

outcome.name: Lymnaeidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands / slower lowland rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, most other dextral snails are much smaller. Lymnaeids can be mottled but they are dextral so they cannot be confused with Physa acuta.

questions.text: Animals look like mussels.
Class level ID. Bivalvia (mussels).

outcome.name: Hyriidae
outcome.habitat: Often found in groups, almost completely dug into the sandy bottom of slow flowing rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Keep going.
Shell halves are large (longer than 25 mm), dark, thick and usually not symmetrical.

outcome.name: Hyriidae
outcome.habitat: Often found in groups, almost completely dug into the sandy bottom of slow flowing rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Shell halves are small (less than 25 mm); light coloured, relatively thin and symmetrical.

outcome.name: Sphaeriidae and Corbiculidae
outcome.habitat: Often found in groups, almost completely dug into the sandy bottom of slow flowing rivers.Flowing and still waters, usually amongst sand or finer sediments. Can be found in large numbers. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Small Hyriidae, but Hyriidae are usually asymmetrical and much larger.

questions.text: Animal without a shell
Animal with legs
With more than eight legs
Robust animals, freshwater crayfish or yabbies with obvious front pincers, movement walking or sometimes 'flips' of the tail that propel the animal backwards.
Oder level ID Decapoda (decapods)

outcome.name: Decapods
outcome.habitat: Rivers and wetlands.

questions.text: Keep going

outcome.name: Parastacidae
outcome.habitat: Crayfish in rivers (with spines) yabbies in wetlands/pools (more leathery).
outcome.movement: walking, with sudden flips when disturbed.
outcome.confusedWith: n            Nothing, very distinctive. We have left crayfish and yabbies grouped togethern            because they mostly turn up as juveniles in samples and are difficult to separate when young.n

questions.text: Not as above.
Shrimp or prawn-like animals.
Oder level ID Decapoda (decapods)

outcome.name: Decapods
outcome.habitat: Rivers and wetlands.

questions.text: Keep going
Second leg with pincers and noticeably longer than others. Body translucent/opaque.

outcome.name: Macrobrachium
outcome.habitat: Lowland rivers on wood or amongst water weeds.
outcome.confusedWith: Atyidae, but pincers on second leg very distinctive when fully grown.

questions.text: Transparent (or at least translucent) front pairs of legs similar sized.

outcome.name: Atyidae
outcome.habitat: slow moving parts of rivers near wood and weeds. Common and often abundant.
outcome.movement: Fast, with lots of flipping when in a tray.
outcome.confusedWith: Palaemonidae, but front 2 pairs of Atyidae legs are shorter and usually with brushes.

questions.text: Not as above.
Round body, slow-moving, obviously crab-like (see image).
Oder level ID Decapoda (decapods)

outcome.name: Decapods
outcome.habitat: Rivers and wetlands.

questions.text: Keep going

outcome.name: Hymenosomatidae
outcome.commonName: five cent crab, false spider crab
outcome.habitat: Lakes, and the sluggish, estuarine ends of rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above.
Animals strongly flattened from the sides (like dogs and cats); often lying on their side or moving with their side flat against the substrate.
Animal rests on its side, swims in swift bursts.

outcome.name: Amphipoda
outcome.habitat: Wetlands. Weeds in slower parts of rivers, or leaf packs in faster rivers. Very Common.
outcome.movement: Bursts of movement, usually on their sides.
outcome.confusedWith: Phreatoicids, but faster.

questions.text: Animal slow moving, walks, relatively robust looking animal, bovine.

outcome.name: Phreatoicidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands. Rivers. Usually not common but can occur in large numbers.
outcome.confusedWith: Amphipods, but they are far more robust looking and slow moving.

questions.text: Animals not flattened or flattened 'front to back' (like humans or cockroaches).
Small, pale (white to light brown or grey) crustacean, final segments as broad or broader than head, slow moving and slater-like.

outcome.name: Janiridae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: If terrestrial slaters fall in they look similar. Can be extremely small.

questions.text: Not as above.
Animal looks like this.

outcome.name: Anostraca
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, salt lakes.
outcome.movement: Constant with pulsing rows of legs.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, but can be difficult to definitively separate natives from pest species.
outcome.description: n          Native fairy shrimp (left) tend to be larger (up to 25mm) and paler coloured, while the introduced sea monkeys (right) tend to be smaller (up to 10mm) and pink or orange. Native fairy shrimp can live in fresh or salty waters, while sea monkeys prefer salty watersn

questions.text: Not as above
Animal looks like this.

outcome.name: Notostraca
outcome.habitat: Wetlands.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing in wetlands ...but they do look like horseshoe crabs.

questions.text: Not as above.

outcome.name: Conchostraca
outcome.habitat: Temporary Wetlands. Common but cryptic and short lived.
outcome.movement: Busy, haphazard then they drop from the water column.
outcome.confusedWith: Some pea shells, but legs are obvious on live animals.

questions.text: With eight legs or less
with eight legs
found under water

outcome.name: Acarina
outcome.habitat: Rivers, wetlands.
outcome.movement: Very active swimmers, legs move very fast.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing else is as colourful.

questions.text: found on the surface of the water, or if underneath, it is covered in a silvery bubble of air.

outcome.name: Pisauridae and Lycosidae
outcome.habitat: Edges of rivers and wetlands.
outcome.movement: Running rapidly on the surface, then crawling underwater leaving a silvery layer of air trapped against the body.
outcome.confusedWith: Terrestrial spiders, which cannot do the air layer trick or run on water as effectively.

questions.text: with six legs
with wing covers
hard wingcovers, symmetrical
Order level ID Coleoptera (beetles)

outcome.name: Beetles
outcome.habitat: Everywhere.
outcome.confusedWith: Bugs can appear similar to adult beetles , but are less rounded dorsally, and have asymetrically folded wings.
outcome.description: An extremely diverse group that occur both as larvae and adults in fresh waters

questions.text: Keep going
Beetles active swimmers
Beetles swim rapidly in circular patterns on the water surface as well as below, shiny beetles with legs tucked neatly under body, often found in groups.

outcome.name: Gyrinidae adult
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges, common and conspicuous.
outcome.movement: Fast, and mainly on the surface in circular patterns, although they will dive underwater if threatened.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, movement and appearance are both very distinctive.

questions.text: Beetles swim submerged, with obvious legs.
Beetles move with all 3 or at least 2 pairs of legs. Legs move alternately.
Always with a black head and a brown body; may screech when in net or tray. Distinctively 'lumpy' appearance; Rare.

outcome.name: Hygrobia adult
outcome.habitat: Wetlands. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, the oddly lumpy appearance is distinctive. Most will screech while being collected.

questions.text: Often black but may be green or brown. Flat on the underside, sometimes with a bubble vest; head bent downwards; Common.

outcome.name: Water scavenger beetle adult
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Common and abundant.
outcome.confusedWith: Dytiscids
outcome.description: very variable size, can be as small as 2mm

questions.text: Beetles appear to swim smoothly with only the rear pair of legs, legs move in unison; motion is like breast stroke. Rear swimming legs held upwards when beetle rests.
less than 10mm
less than 4mm
Body segment associated with first pair of legs constricted to give the beetle a distinctly waisted look.

outcome.name: Carabhydrus
outcome.habitat: Running water. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, strong constriction of the pronotum is distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above.
Conspicuous lateral stripes, water-drop shaped beetles.

outcome.name: Australphilus
outcome.habitat: Running water. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, strong colour pattern and tapered body are distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above.

outcome.name: little diving beetles
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers.
outcome.movement: Strong swimmer using hind legs, rarely stops moving.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, most of the medium beetles should be noticeably larger.

questions.text: greater than 4mm
Beetles with some form of colour pattern (variable patterns: mottled, brindled, stripes or patches.)

outcome.name: mixed diving beetles
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Anything with a pattern in this size class is considered the same.

questions.text: Beetles totally lack colour. Black.

outcome.name: stealth diving beetles
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and Rivers.
outcome.movement: Some of these may move quite slowly for diving beetles.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, black. May sometimes have a light coloured spot on the head.

questions.text: larger than 10mm
less than 15mm
Beetle with distinctive longitudinal stripes (like a pin-stripe).

outcome.name: Lancetes
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive stripes.

questions.text: Beetle without longitudinal stripes
Beetle with dark patch in middle of head, body pale underneath.

outcome.name: Eretes
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Rhantus, but colour patterns are different, note Eretes has a pale coloured underside.

questions.text: Beetle with light patch in middle of head, body dark underneath.

outcome.name: Rhantus
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Eretes, see above.

questions.text: larger than 15mm
Beetle black / dark.

outcome.name: Hyderodes
outcome.habitat: Temporary wetlands.
outcome.confusedWith: Large hydrophilid beetles, but hydrophilids are flat underneath.

questions.text: Beetle green.
Beetle with dark undersides. Never larger than 20mm.

outcome.name: Spencerhydrus
outcome.habitat: Temporary wetlands.
outcome.confusedWith: Onychohydrus, but Onychohydrus is usually larger and pale underneath. (Photo is actually Onychohydrus ...but they are very, very similar).

questions.text: Beetle with orange undersides. Often larger than 20mm.

outcome.name: Onychohydrus
outcome.habitat: Temporary wetlands.
outcome.confusedWith: Spencerhydrus, but Spencerhydrus is smaller and dark/black underneath.

questions.text: Beetles crawl (or don't move much).
Beetle has a distinct 'nose' or snout.

outcome.name: Curculionidae
outcome.habitat: Vegetation in wetlands.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, it has a distinctive nose.

questions.text: Beetle has no 'nose'. (How does it smell?)
Small to tiny beetles with well-developed claws, usually black, sometimes dark brown or red, with a shiny plastron or bubble vest; slow moving, sometimes hang motionless mid-water.

outcome.name: Elmidae adult
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing waters (riffles), often found on wood, common but hard to see.
outcome.movement: Hangs in the water or clings to detritus, slow.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very few beetles are as slow or with such impressive claws. Often overlooked due to size.

questions.text: Not as above, may crawl on the underside of the water surface.
Small to tiny, elongate, often metallic beetles. Rare

outcome.name: Hydraenidae and Hydrochidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, wet rock surfaces near waterfalls. Uncommon, but can be abundant. Hydraenids in wetlands can walk on the water undersurface.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, quite distinctive.

questions.text: Larger dull coloured beetles sometimes with prominent yellow egg sac.

outcome.name: Helochares
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, river edges.
outcome.movement: Slow, sometimes walk on the water undersurface.
outcome.confusedWith: Other hydrophilids, but Helochares does not swim.

questions.text: leathery wingcovers, asymmetrical
Order level ID Hemiptera (true bugs).

outcome.name: Hemiptera
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow river sections. Still water, very common.
outcome.confusedWith: Beetles, but beetles have their wings separated symetrically.

questions.text: Keep going.
Bugs walking/running on the water surface.
Short bodied bugs that move quickly on the water surface.
Bugs with very long hind and middle legs. Move with a skating/sculling motion.

outcome.name: Gerridae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Small to tiny bugs with shorter legs, running on the water surface.

outcome.name: Veliidae, Mesoveliidae and Hebridae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Very common.
outcome.movement: Fast, look a bit like they have been sped up.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing. If they are in large numbers and are dark or black they are probably Veliidae (two lower photos). Pale individuals are likely to be Mesoveliidae (top photo). Hebridae are relatively rare.

questions.text: Elongate bugs with antennae at the very tip of the head. Walk slowly on water surface.

outcome.name: Hydrometridae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water. Uncommon, but very cool.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Bugs swimming below the surface.
Bugs walk or swim awkwardly.
Ugly dark brown bugs with wide heads and a warty appearance. Pointed, grasping front legs. Semi-aquatic.

outcome.name: Gelastocoridae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Rare.
outcome.movement: Slow, ponderous, but surprisingly can jump.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Large (>20mm), elongate bugs with front legs for grabbing prey. Body stick or leaf like. Long legs. Long breathing tube at hind end.
Long, thin, skinny bug, pale coloured. Looks like a stick or a piece of sedge.

outcome.name: Ranatra
outcome.habitat: Still water. Uncommon but spectacular.
outcome.movement: Swims awkwardly or not at all (sit-and-wait predator).
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Long flattened bug, dark or black. Looks like a leaf.

outcome.name: Laccotrephes
outcome.habitat: Wetlands. Still water. Uncommon but spectacular.
outcome.movement: Slow or not at all (sit-and-wait predator).
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Bugs swim well.
Bugs swim upside down, with legs uppermost, dark on upper surface, lighter coloured underneath.
Tiny orange bugs with a highly convex humped back. No prominent swimming legs. Look a bit like a tiny, mobile jelly bean.

outcome.name: Pleidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Common but cryptic.
outcome.confusedWith: Immature Notonectidae.

questions.text: Elongate bugs with two prominent, narrow swimming legs. Swim with a jerky motion. Very active. Obviously dark on one side (top) and light on the other (underneath).
Robust, chunky, fast moving. Either at water surface or holding onto something. Triangular when viewed from above (animal on left of image).

outcome.name: Enithares
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow river sections. Still water, very common.
outcome.movement: In bursts. Still when it is at the surface re-filling air supplies.
outcome.confusedWith: Slender backswimmers Anisops.

questions.text: Slender, relaxed, unhurried movement. Able to stay still mid-water (thanks to buoyancy regulation). Thinner and parallel sided when viewed from above (animal on right of image).

outcome.name: Anisops
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow river sections. Still water, very common
outcome.movement: Deliberate strokes of swimming legs, sometimes still, mid-water. Less relaxed in an ice cube tray.
outcome.confusedWith: Younger robust backswimmers Enithares.

questions.text: Bugs swim the right way up, with legs beneath them, wings on the upper surface if present.
Larger 10-30mm bugs. Front legs pointed for piercing prey. Do not flick swimming legs when at rest.
Medium sized bugs (10-15mm) with broad heads and light/dark checks (taxi stripes) along their sides.

outcome.name: Naucoris
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and weedy river edges. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Giant water bugs (Belostomatidae)

questions.text: Larger bugs (up to 30mm) without checks. Flattened body, narrower heads.

outcome.name: Diplonychus
outcome.habitat: Wetlands. Uncommon.
outcome.confusedWith: Creeping water bugs (Naucoridae).

questions.text: Small (<10mm) active bugs with two broad paddle like swimming legs which they flick back and forth when at rest. Streamlined body, blunt head. An air bubble may be visible under the body. May make buzzing or squeaking sounds in the tray.
Head with 'nostrils' (Ocelli, they are more like eyes - see photo). Usually distinctly orange or yellow coloured head and underneath.

outcome.name: Diaprepocoris barycephala
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow river sections. Slow moving water.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above.
Segment after the head (pronotum) with distinctive stripes or bands (see photo) you need a hand lens to see this.

outcome.name: Sigara
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow river sections. Slow moving water. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above.
Small boatmen (<4mm), mottled or brindle wing covers (see photo). By far the commonest corixid.

outcome.name: Micronecta
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow river sections. Very very common. Often found in large numbers (see soup picture).
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Large boatmen (>4mm) brown /yellow /grey, markings are not distinctive, looks a lot like television static (pre-digital telly). Unlike all of the above. Rare.

outcome.name: Agraptocorixa
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and slow river sections. Slow moving water. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: All other boatmen if small.

questions.text: with no wing covers, possibly with wing buds
no obvious tails
with a case. Sometimes the case may be lost. Look for small, terminal, lateral hooks on the abdomen or ventral pro-legs on the abdomen.
long legs,case never with coarse vegetation badly attached lengthways
Order level ID Trichoptera (caddisflies)

outcome.name: Caddis
outcome.habitat: flowing water, edges, riffles. Common.
outcome.movement: usually fairly quick unless playing possum.
outcome.description: The Trichoptera are considered sensitive to pollution.

questions.text: Keep going
Caddis living in a portable case. Most crawl slowly, some swim by head-thrashing or arm-waving; if out of case, body blunt ending with tiny prolegs and hooks.
Tiny larvae <5mm long. Abdomen yellow, swollen, thicker than thorax. Purse shaped case of translucent silk, sometimes with sand or algae. Slow moving, hard to see.

outcome.name: Hydroptilidae
outcome.habitat: All water bodies, cases vary accordingly.
outcome.movement: Slow moving, don't move at all immediately after being disturbed...will need 10-15 minutes to get over shock.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive ...but small.

questions.text: Not as above.
Fang-shaped case made from fine particles, sometimes with a groove. Hind legs curved like talons, head pointy, all body segments covered in hairs.

outcome.name: Atriplectides
outcome.habitat: Lakes and rivers amongst deposits of sand and debris where it finds carrion. Uncommon, but very cool.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive. Notice the way the hind legs are held out of the way when moving, and mainly get used to latch onto food.

questions.text: Not as above.
Case made mainly from sand.
Case like a messy sand igloo. Larvae fall out easily. Slow moving.

outcome.name: Agapetus
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing waters, forest streams, riffles. Uncommon, but abundant when they do occur.
outcome.confusedWith: Coarser case might look like Tasimiidae, but glossosomatids don't have tapered/triangular cases.

questions.text: Case not like a messy sand igloo.
Case appears round but is actually coiled like a snail shell. Active but slow moving.

outcome.name: Helicopsyche
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, forest streams, riffles. Rare, but can be abundant.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, extremely distinctive ...maybe hydrobiid snails.

questions.text: Case not like a snail shell.
Case triangular, often with larger particles down each side. Eyes of larvae protrude when viewed from above.

outcome.name: Tasimiidae
outcome.habitat: Small mountain streams, amongst coarse, stable substrate.
outcome.confusedWith: Glossosomatidae. Tasimiids have bulgy eyes if you can get close enough to look at their heads and coarser, triangular cases.

questions.text: Case tubular, legs sharp, for grabbing prey. Fast deliberate movement.
Animal found in highland site

outcome.name: Philorheithridae
outcome.habitat: Cold flowing water, edges, riffles. Common but sparse (as are most predators).
outcome.confusedWith: Young leptocerids have a tubular sand case, but they have much longer hind legs.

questions.text: Animal found in a lowland site

outcome.name: Some Oecetis sp. (Leptoceridae) and Odontoceridae
outcome.habitat: Cold flowing water, edges, riffles. Common but sparse (as are most predators).
outcome.confusedWith: Young leptocerids have a tubular sand case, but they have much longer hind legs.

questions.text: Case made from plant material or silk secretion but may incorporate some mineral particles.
Case made from flat pieces of leaf, giving it a flat appearance overall.
Case built from 2 flat pieces of leaf, the dorsal piece is slightly larger forming a 'veranda'.

outcome.name: Anisocentropus
outcome.habitat: Slow flowing water, backwaters, edges, in leaf packs. Uncommon.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above
Case built from many round, shingle-like bits of leaf, in two distinct rows.

outcome.name: Caenota plicata
outcome.habitat: Slow flowing water, backwaters, edges, in leaf packs. Uncommon.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Case built from a messy assortment of leaf plates, but still flat. Sometimes tapered quite severely.

outcome.name: Lectrides varians
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, lakes and pools in rivers. Common and often abundant.
outcome.confusedWith: Case is superficially similar to the shingle caddis, but Lectrides' cases are messy and lack the neat double row of leaf plates.

questions.text: Case made from all sorts, including: silk secretion, sticks, or other plant material and sometimes sand (never leaf plates by themselves). Case not flat.
Larvae with short legs, head compact, bullet like. Case often made with rings of different colours, sometimes with sand or may look like orange plastic. Slow moving, never swimming.

outcome.name: Conoesucidae, Calocidae and Helicophidae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, riffles.
outcome.confusedWith: Young leptocerids; the distinction between long and short hind legs is not as great with juveniles.

questions.text: Larvae with long legs; may swim by thrashing their head about. Case variable.
Case constructed from a single stick or piece of aquatic plant.

outcome.name: Triplectides
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, lakes, slow flowing sections in rivers. Common and often abundant.
outcome.confusedWith: All stick cases are from the Genus Triplectides, but not all Triplectides have stick cases.

questions.text: Not as above.
Case constructed like a log cabin, square in cross section (see photo).

outcome.name: Oecetis
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, lakes pools in rivers.
outcome.movement: Hovers with flailing arms, like a helicopter.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, the case is unique.

questions.text: Not as above.
Case with sand or fine gravel at the opening (front) and the rest of the case made from pieces of vegetation.

outcome.name: Symphitoneuria
outcome.habitat: Lower end of rivers.
outcome.movement: Crawls on veg, when dislodged, the case falls like a dart with the heavy end first (the sandy bit).
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, case is distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above.
Case made from a variety of materials, may be arranged spirally (but not always). When disturbed animal flails its body in a head-banging motion.

outcome.name: Notalina
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, lakes and pools in rivers. Common and often abundant.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, case and movement are distinctive.
outcome.description: Notalina are special for the way they move. They thrash their thorax, head and legs back and forth to move through the water. This exhausting movement earns them the name head banger caddis. They always have slender cases. Cases can sometimes be made of spirally arrangedn              bits of vegetation

questions.text: Not as above. Generally a mix of caddis with long hind legs and mixed messy cases

outcome.name: Leptocerids
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, lakes, slow flowing sections in rivers. Common and often abundant.
outcome.confusedWith: Double check you haven't got Triplectides or one of the other distinctive caddises from this group.

questions.text: Free-living caddis, body, long abdominal pro-legs with prominent claws.
Order level ID Trichoptera (caddisflies)

outcome.name: Caddis
outcome.habitat: flowing water, edges, riffles. Common.
outcome.movement: usually fairly quick unless playing possum.
outcome.description: The Trichoptera are considered sensitive to pollution.

questions.text: Keep going
All three thoracic segments hard or sclerotised, they appear darker or different in colour to the soft abdomen.
Abdominal gills present (hairy chest), slow moving. May undulate abdomen to ventilate gills. To 15mm.

outcome.name: Hydropsychidae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, riffles. Common.
outcome.movement: Slow moving, sometimes thrashes in open water. Will undulate the abdomen to aerate their gills.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive once you have noticed the 'hairy chest' of gills on the abdomen.

questions.text: Abdominal gills absent, often with a pattern on the head like a bandits mask.

outcome.name: Ecnomus
outcome.habitat: Still and flowing water, edges. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Some hunter caddis have a similar head pattern. They are relatively fast moving and 'quest' with their front legs for prey, while ecnomids are less active, and have all three leg-bearing segments sclerotised (hardened).

questions.text: Only the first thoracic segment sclerotised.
Larvae often green when alive. Forelegs modified into a pincer, or broad with a large spine. Larvae hunt from side to side with the forelegs.

outcome.name: Hydrobiosidae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, riffles, and forest streams. Common.
outcome.movement: Fast moving, hunt with front legs in front of their body on the off-chance they might hit prey.
outcome.confusedWith: see Ecnomidae.

questions.text: Larvae without pincers, body not green. Often pale, head brown or yellow. Don't tend to hunt actively.

outcome.name: Philopotamidae, Polycentropodidae and Ecnomidae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, riffles, edges, forest streams. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: short, stumpy legs, case with coarse vegetation badly attached lengthways

outcome.name: Lepidoptera
outcome.habitat: Slow moving or still water in amongst aquatic vegetation.
outcome.confusedWith: Beetle larvae or uncased caddis larvae, but caterpillars have rows of extra grasping organs along their abdomen.

questions.text: without a case
with wingbuds and well developed compound eyes
Order level ID Odonata (dragonflies and damselflies).

outcome.name: spider mud eye
outcome.habitat: Rivers and wetlands.

questions.text: Keep going.
Slender larvae, with 3 terminal gills. Swim by undulating (snake-like).
Leaf-like terminal gills held flat and fanned out horizontally.

outcome.name: Megapodagrionidae
outcome.habitat: Occurs in slow flowing waters, at the edges of streams, in bogs and seepages. Uncommon.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, unless it has lost its gills.

questions.text: Gills different in shape or orientation.
Gills shorter than last 3 abdominal segments

outcome.name: Synlestidae
outcome.habitat: At the edge of streams amongst tree roots and vegetation. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, unless it has lost its gills.

questions.text: Gills equal in length or longer than last 3 abdominal segments.
Gills divided into two parts by constriction.

outcome.name: Isostictidae
outcome.habitat: At the edge of streams amongst tree roots and vegetation. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Will look almost exactly like a synlestid (stripy legs and all), but with longer, obviously divided gills.

questions.text: Gills complete, without constriction.
Gills sack-like, with hairy ends.

outcome.name: Diphlebiidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, or slow moving water in rivers.
outcome.movement: Slow, but may swim with a sideways undulating motion if disturbed.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, unless it has lost its gills.

questions.text: Gills leaf like.

outcome.name: Lestidae and Coenagrionidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, or slow moving water in rivers. Very common and sometimes abundant.
outcome.movement: Slow, but may swim with a rapid sideways undulating motion if disturbed.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, unless it has lost its gills.

questions.text: Robust larvae, without terminal gills. Swim by jetting water out of their bums.
Fat, round ended body and long legs make them look spider-like. Mouthparts form a ladle-shaped mask in front of face.

outcome.name: spider mud eye
outcome.habitat: Slow flowing waters, among detritus and silt.
outcome.movement: Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed.

questions.text: Relatively elongate body, NOT spider-like. Mouthparts flat, folded under 'chin'
Medium sized nymphs with club or sausage shaped antennae. Sluggish, often green or brown. No obvious spines on the edges of abdominal segments.

outcome.name: Gomphidae
outcome.habitat: Rivers, among detritus and silt, and sometimes wetlands or lakes.
outcome.movement: Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing so long as you get a good look at the antennae. These are obvious even on juveniles.

questions.text: Large nymphs with tiny antennae and with spines on the edges of the abdominal segments.
Dark mottled nymphs usually with large spines on the edges of the abdominal segments. Central bum-spine pointed.

outcome.name: Telephlebiidae
outcome.habitat: Rivers. Common.
outcome.movement: Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed.
outcome.confusedWith: Note the 'Humbug' patterned juvenile is similar to Aeshnidae

questions.text: Green or brown nymphs. Central bum-spine with a cut-off end. This can be seen even on small nymphs.

outcome.name: Aeshnidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, slow rivers or lakes. Common.
outcome.movement: Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed.
outcome.confusedWith: Telephlebiidae.

questions.text: without wing buds, eyes simple dots
mouthparts straight and longer than head

outcome.name: Neuroptera
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing streams.
outcome.movement: Very fast moving (underwater)or slow moving (semi terrestrial)
outcome.confusedWith: Beetle larvae, but lacewings often have a distinct neck and their jaws are longer and straighter.

questions.text: mouthparts short and curved or too small to see
animals with a single row of projections along the sides of the abdomen
7 or 8 abdominal projections (dangly bits), found in rivers
Order level ID Megaloptera (Dobson flies and Alderflies)

outcome.name: Megaloptera
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing stony rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Gyrinid and Hydrophilid beetle larvae, which are much smaller and are not found in fast flowing rivers.

questions.text: Keep going
robust animal, distinctive, abdominal projections robust (see image), found in cobbly rivers

outcome.name: Corydalidae
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing stony rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Gyrinid and Hydrophilid beetle larvae, which are much smaller and are not found in fast flowing rivers.

questions.text: slender animal, or with slender abdominal projections (dangly bits), found in pools and wetlands

outcome.name: Sialidae
outcome.habitat: Slow flowing rivers.
outcome.confusedWith: Gyrinid and Hydrophilid beetle larvae, which are slightly smaller and don't end in a single long filament.

questions.text: 10 abdominal projections (dangly bits), found in pools and wetlands
Order level ID Coleoptera (beetles)

outcome.name: Beetles
outcome.habitat: Everywhere.
outcome.confusedWith: Bugs can appear similar to adult beetles , but are less rounded dorsally, and have asymetrically folded wings.
outcome.description: An extremely diverse group that occur both as larvae and adults in fresh waters

questions.text: Keep going

Beetle larvae swim actively with all legs; usually with wide flat heads and prominent mandibles; middle of the head sometimes projected forwards like a nose on smaller examples; may be biting and killing other animals in the tray.
Larvae larger than 12mm long.
Larvae without a pair of tails. Last segment tapers to a point and is fringed with swimming hairs.

outcome.name: taper-tailed tiger larvae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands / temporary water.
outcome.confusedWith: Some two-tailed tigers will have smallish tails, so you might need to check with a hand lens.

questions.text: Larvae with two distinct tails

outcome.name: two-tailed tiger larvae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands / temporary water.
outcome.confusedWith: See taper-tailed tigers.Small individuals might key out as swimming water tigers, but swimming water tigers usually have better developed tails.

questions.text: Larvae shorter than 12mm long.
Larvae with a strong 'nose'.

outcome.name: nosey tiger larvae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Very common.
outcome.confusedWith: BEWARE: These animals have a pair of tails, or 2 tails and a siphon, so can potentially end up ID'd as stoneflies or mayflies.

questions.text: Larvae without a nose.
Larvae strong swimmers, constantly moving, obvious tails.

outcome.name: swimming water tiger larvae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Small individuals from the two-tailed tigers will unavoidably key out as swimming water tigers.

questions.text: Larvae crawl slowly, tails minute.

outcome.name: crawling water tiger larvae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and temporary waters.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, all the other dytiscid larvae will be fast moving.

questions.text: Beetle larvae crawl slowly, or, may propel themselves by longitudinal thrashing of the body.
Strongly flattened, round, slater-like larvae, on rocks.

outcome.name: Sclerocyphon
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing water.
outcome.confusedWith: Trilobites, but they have been extinct since the Carboniferous (280,000,000 years ago), and are marine.

questions.text: Not as above.
Elongate slow moving larvae with hard bodies and short legs; often dark coloured, flowing water.
Flattened, cockroach-like larvae with simple bodies and long antennae. Yellow, brown to black.

outcome.name: Scirtidae
outcome.habitat: Flowing water, wetlands, river edges. Fairly common.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, the flattened shape and long antennae are good characters.

questions.text: Larvae with short antennae, not obviously flattened.
Small to tiny and often comma shaped.

outcome.name: Elmidae larvae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water. Very common. Often found on wood.
outcome.movement: Slow or still, very difficult to see, some species are very small and camouflaged.....good luck.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, but often overlooked.

questions.text: Larger more elongate larvae shiny, water repellent skin. Sometimes stuck in water surface tension.

outcome.name: Byrrocryptus
outcome.habitat: cool flowing water, river edges.
outcome.movement: Slow, often holding onto vegetation, or trapped in surface tension.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing.

questions.text: Soft bodied larvae, still and flowing water.
Elongate, slender larvae with feathery lateral gills and terminal anal claws (see picture); head dark, body pale.

outcome.name: Gyrinidae larvae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges. Uncommon.
outcome.movement: Fast, mix of swimming with legs and undulating the abdomen.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, feathery projections are distinctive, may need a hand lens to see these.

questions.text: Robust larvae, without feathery gills but may have long lateral filaments; large head with prominent mandibles.
Abdomen with long lateral filaments.

outcome.name: Berosus
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, river edges.
outcome.confusedWith: Gyrinid larvae, but the lateral filaments on Berosus lack feathering, and Berosus is rarely as slender.

questions.text: Not as above.
Large beetle larvae (up to 50mm). Dark head that is angled upwards.

outcome.name: Hydrophilus
outcome.habitat: Wetlands.
outcome.movement: Slow crawl or swimming with all legs.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing. Nothing else gets this big.

questions.text: Not as above.

outcome.name: Water scavenger beetle larvae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands and river edges.
outcome.confusedWith: Juvenile ugly bobs (Hydrophilus) are difficult to tell apart, but they have darker heads that are angled/kinked up. For water scavenger beetle larvae the head is in line with the rest of the body.

questions.text: animals without a single row of projections (may have a mess of gills)
Order level ID Trichoptera (caddisflies)

outcome.name: Caddis
outcome.habitat: flowing water, edges, riffles. Common.
outcome.movement: usually fairly quick unless playing possum.
outcome.description: The Trichoptera are considered sensitive to pollution.

questions.text: Keep going
All three thoracic segments hard or sclerotised, they appear darker or different in colour to the soft abdomen.
Abdominal gills present (hairy chest), slow moving. May undulate abdomen to ventilate gills. To 15mm.

outcome.name: Hydropsychidae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, riffles. Common.
outcome.movement: Slow moving, sometimes thrashes in open water. Will undulate the abdomen to aerate their gills.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive once you have noticed the 'hairy chest' of gills on the abdomen.

questions.text: Abdominal gills absent, often with a pattern on the head like a bandits mask.

outcome.name: Ecnomus
outcome.habitat: Still and flowing water, edges. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Some hunter caddis have a similar head pattern. They are relatively fast moving and 'quest' with their front legs for prey, while ecnomids are less active, and have all three leg-bearing segments sclerotised (hardened).

questions.text: Only the first thoracic segment sclerotised.
Larvae often green when alive. Forelegs modified into a pincer, or broad with a large spine. Larvae hunt from side to side with the forelegs.

outcome.name: Hydrobiosidae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, riffles, and forest streams. Common.
outcome.movement: Fast moving, hunt with front legs in front of their body on the off-chance they might hit prey.
outcome.confusedWith: see Ecnomidae.

questions.text: Larvae without pincers, body not green. Often pale, head brown or yellow. Don't tend to hunt actively.

outcome.name: Philopotamidae, Polycentropodidae and Ecnomidae
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, riffles, edges, forest streams. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: with obvious tails
with two tails
with compound eyes (like a mirror ball upclose) and wing buds (except on very young animals)
Order level ID Plecoptera (Stoneflies)

outcome.name: Stoneflies
outcome.habitat: Rivers.
outcome.movement: Variable, but usually slow walk or side to side lizard-like gate
outcome.confusedWith: Mayflies with damaged tails.
outcome.description: Stoneflies are some of the most sensitive waterbugs to water quality.

questions.text: Keep going
Large nymphs up to 40mm usually bright green, orange or blue. Animals have gills along the side of the abdomen.

outcome.name: Eustheniidae
outcome.habitat: Upland streams, more often in alpine and sub-alpine areas.
outcome.movement: Deliberate, may try and crawl out of picking tray.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, robust, and distinctively coloured.

questions.text: Smaller nymphs, less flamboyantly coloured, with gills on the tip of the abdomen or with no visible gills.
Nymphs with two long tails. (These could be broken leaving only stumps). Gills either absent or look like a tuft or pom-pom at the end of the abdomen.
External gills form tuft at the tip of the abdomen earning them the common name of 'fluffy bums'. Often wag their abdomen to oxygenate the gills.
Smaller nymphs, brown or black with a single row or ridge of triangular projections along their back.

outcome.name: Riekoperla
outcome.habitat: Upland streams.
outcome.confusedWith: Other gripops, you will need to look at these animals from the side to make sure you see the projections.

questions.text: No triangular projections along their back.
Large, sprawling nymphs with hairy legs, hairs dark and conspicuous. Often with high contrast patterns

outcome.name: Hairy sprawler
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing rivers and streams.
outcome.movement: Slow, sometimes flex side to side while unattached.
outcome.confusedWith: Other gripops can be similar. With a white background you can be more confident that you haven't missed the dark, extremely hairy legs.

questions.text: Not as above.
Large, sprawling nymphs, hairs pale if present. Blond, never darkly patterned.

outcome.name: Illiesoperla
outcome.habitat: Rivers and streams.
outcome.movement: Slow, sometimes flex side to side while unattached.
outcome.confusedWith: Hairy sprawlers can appear similar. However, with a white background and a hand lens, you can be more confident that you haven't just missed the hairy legs. Illiesoperla can have hairs on its legs, but never long dark ones, and often has light purple gills. Sometimes beigen              or brown rather than blond.

questions.text: Not as above.

outcome.name: Gripops or Fluffy bums
outcome.habitat: Rivers and wetlands.
outcome.confusedWith: This is a diverse group of leftovers, check carefully for projections and hairy legs before using this name.

questions.text: Smaller nymphs with no gills on the tip of the abdomen. May also wag, but don't have fluffy gills.

outcome.name: Notonemouridae
outcome.habitat: Occurs in small upland streams and in small lowland streams. Sometimes found in wetlands.
outcome.confusedWith: Gripops that have retracted their gill tufts will key out here. Look closely with a hand lens, also check for tail wagging, a characteristically gripop behaviour.
outcome.description: Notice the 'alert' posture. Inset photo shows the abdomen without gills.

questions.text: Nymphs with short tails, shorter than half the length of the abdomen. Only 3 or 5 gills, which are similar in length and thickness to the tails.
Nymphs with a double row of spines along their backs.
Mainland.

outcome.name: Acruroperla atra
outcome.habitat: Often associated with submerged wood in upland streams.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, one of the snazziest stonefly nymphs you will see.

questions.text: Tasmania.

outcome.name: Crypturoperla paradoxa
outcome.habitat: Rivers and streams in Tasmania.
outcome.movement: Slow, sometimes flex side to side while unattached.
outcome.confusedWith: Acruroperla atra looks sim ilar but is from the mainland.

questions.text: Nymphs without a double row of spines.

outcome.name: Austroperlids
outcome.habitat: Cool upland forested streams, often amongst bark and leaf litter.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, the short tails and long abdomen are good characters.

questions.text: simple eyes (several dots), never with wing pads
Order level ID Coleoptera (beetles)

outcome.name: Beetles
outcome.habitat: Everywhere.
outcome.confusedWith: Bugs can appear similar to adult beetles , but are less rounded dorsally, and have asymetrically folded wings.
outcome.description: An extremely diverse group that occur both as larvae and adults in fresh waters

outcome.movement: Fast, mix of swimming with legs and undulating the abdomen.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, feathery projections are distinctive, may need a hand lens to see these.

Abdomen with long lateral filaments.

outcome.habitat: Wetlands, river edges.
outcome.confusedWith: Gyrinid larvae, but the lateral filaments on Berosus lack feathering, and Berosus is rarely as slender.

outcome.habitat: Wetlands.
outcome.movement: Slow crawl or swimming with all legs.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing. Nothing else gets this big.

tails flattened or broad, jaw large and folded away under head

outcome.name: spider mud eye
outcome.habitat: Slow flowing waters, among detritus and silt.
outcome.movement: Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed.

questions.text: Relatively elongate body, NOT spider-like. Mouthparts flat, folded under 'chin'

outcome.name: Gomphidae
outcome.habitat: Rivers, among detritus and silt, and sometimes wetlands or lakes.
outcome.movement: Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed.

outcome.habitat: Rivers. Common.

outcome.habitat: Wetlands, slow rivers or lakes. Common.
outcome.movement: Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed.

questions.text: tails thin, round in cross section
Order level ID Ephemeroptera (mayflies)

outcome.name: Mayflies
outcome.habitat: Rivers.
outcome.movement: Variable, some swim rapidly like little fish, others walk or thrash
outcome.confusedWith: Mayflies with damaged tails might look like stoneflies (2 tails).
outcome.description: Mayflies are some of the most sensitive waterbugs to water quality.

questions.text: Keep going
Nymphs with gills along the side of the abdomen.
Robust dark brown nymphs with alternating spiny V-shaped gills and smaller feathery gills. Move with a distinct rocking horse motion. Large thorax giving a hunched appearance.

outcome.name: Coloburiscoides
outcome.habitat: Cool upland streams. Common and abundant in healthy boulder streams.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive in robustness and movement. Look for spiky V shaped gills for confirmation.

questions.text: Not as above.
Large nymphs with helmet-like heads and prominent eyes; two different types of gill which are flicked in sync; crawl slowly but can swim rapidly.

outcome.name: Mirawara
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing cool cobbly streams. Rare.
outcome.movement: Fast and searching for prey. Regularly 'shuffles' gills.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive head shape and size.

questions.text: Not as above head not helmet like, upper and lower gills similar.
Nymphs usually run rather than swim, but can 'dolphin' clumsily if disturbed. Conspicuously flattened nymphs, head square. Legs sprawling with wide, flat femurs.
With a conspicuous set of horns.

outcome.name: Jappa
outcome.habitat: Slower flowing rivers. Rare.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing else has horns.

questions.text: Not as above.
Gills fluffy, each one ending in many fingers making them look like tinsel.

outcome.name: Atalophlebia
outcome.habitat: Slower flowing waters, sometimes wetlands. Very common.
outcome.movement: Can sometimes 'dolphin' when disturbed, but otherwise walks.
outcome.confusedWith: Other leptophlebs, but the banded legs and fluffy gills are VERY distinctive.

questions.text: Not as above.

outcome.name: Leptophlebs
outcome.habitat: Cool running water. Very common.
outcome.movement: Scurry, then stay still. A bit like a huntsman spider, can sometimes 'dolphin' when disturbed.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing.

questions.text: Nymphs are fast swimmers, but swim in bursts like tiny fish. Nymphs not flattened or sprawling, head bullet shaped. Tails fringed with hairs.
Large nymphs up to 17mm. Antennae shorter than head. Rare.

outcome.name: Siphlonuridae
outcome.habitat: Cool, fish free alpine streams and lakes. Very rare.
outcome.movement: Walks slowly, infrequent bursts of movement.
outcome.confusedWith: Baetids, but baetids are generally smaller, and have long antennae.

questions.text: Small nymphs less than 10mm. Antennae longer than head. Common.

outcome.name: Baetidae
outcome.habitat: Still and flowing waters. Common.
outcome.movement: Bursts of movement like a tiny fish.
outcome.confusedWith: Siphlonurids.

questions.text: Nymphs with no visible gills along the sides of the abdomen; gill covers over part of the abdomen; gill covers can look like wing buds but are always behind the last pair of legs.
Very small <5mm grey brown nymphs with a fuzzy silt covered appearance. Slow moving but may swim lazily. Flat gill covers large, meeting along the midline like a mini skirt.

outcome.name: Caenidae
outcome.habitat: Still and slow moving waters with silty areas. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive once you have seen the square gill covers.

questions.text: Larger nymphs with a camouflage pattern and eyes which may appear to shine in bright light. Rarely crawl but swim rapidly. Gill covers small, elliptical, not meeting in the middle.

outcome.name: Tasmanophlebia
outcome.habitat: Cool flowing water, edges, backwaters, forest streams. Uncommon.
outcome.confusedWith: baetids if you don't see the gill covers.

questions.text: Animal without legs
segmented
without suction cups
with hard mouthparts (these can be inside the head and difficult to see)
Order level ID Diptera (maggots or true fly larvae)

outcome.name: maggots
outcome.habitat: Everywhere.

questions.text: Keep going
Maggots break the surface of the water to breathe; their bodies are buoyant in deeper water (floaters).
Animal has obviously sclerotised (armoured or hardened) body plates, either the whole body or bands on all segments.
All of body sclerotised (darkened and toughened skin), animal can grow to 20mm.

outcome.name: Stratiomyidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water, salt lakes. Common.
outcome.movement: Slow moving almost still but floating.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive amount of sclerotisation and usually suspended from surface by its rear end.

questions.text: Only bands of the upper surface of the body are sclerotised, smaller than 6mm.

outcome.name: Psychodidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water. Often overlooked.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive once you have found them. Might look stripy like some elmid beetle larvae.

questions.text: Animal mostly soft bodied, although it may have sclerotised plates on its head and abdomen.
Animals with obviously sclerotised (dark) head capsule and final segments.
Animal restricted to the water surface, bent 'U' posture at rest, final segments usually out of the water so they distort the surface.

outcome.name: Dixidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water, the edges of farm dams. Uncommon.
outcome.movement: Bend and unbend just under water surface.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, the large plate that punctures the surface (like an air anchor) and the movement are unique.

questions.text: Often dive when disturbed, leaving the surface quite readily, move in a rapid tumbling or wriggling motion.

outcome.name: Culicidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water, even buckets left out for too long. Common.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive and well known to most people.

questions.text: Not as above.
Animal with a distinctive elongate tail (a snorkel).

outcome.name: Syrphidae
outcome.habitat: Still, nutrient rich (liquid faeces) waters.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Animal with very few characteristics of note, maggot-like in appearance.

outcome.name: Ephydridae and Sciomyzidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water, Ephydrids in salty lakes. Widespread.
outcome.confusedWith: Most things maggoty, the short body and welts are good clues. This group NEVER has tassels.

questions.text: Maggots don't need contact with the water surface, bodies are not buoyant in deeper water, may still be active and swim past the surface (sinkers).
Bleffs (very distinctive, see picture), only found in fast flowing water.

outcome.name: Blephariceridae
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing streams with stable boulders, lives in the fastest bits.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Not a bleff.
Animal with a head capsule; long, thin, worm-like or leech-like body form and movement.

Animal moves like a leech, rarely losing hold of the substrate, abdomen broadly swollen giving a 'chicken drumstick' appearance, expandable antennae modified to form broad 'antlers' for filter feeding; typical of fast flowing waters with solid surfaces.

outcome.name: Simuliidae
outcome.habitat: Fast flowing waters. Common and abundant.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, other than chicken drumsticks. Very distinctive.

questions.text: Animal moves by coiling and uncoiling, or by rapid undulations. Unattached to the substrate; abdomen may be swollen but only the very end; antennae small and simple if present.
Animals obviously red.

outcome.name: Chironomus
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water. Common.
outcome.movement: : Coil and uncoil quickly in a figure of eight, sometimes thrashing or using prolegs to drag themselves along the ground.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive.

questions.text: Colour variable but not red.
Animal looks like a swimming eyelash, with stiff, snake-like movements.

outcome.name: Ceratopogonidae
outcome.habitat: Wetlands, still water, river edges. Common.
outcome.movement: Like a stiff snake, or a swimming eyelash, very distinctive.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive movement, and nothing else has the pointy head.

questions.text: Not as above.
Head capsule obvious, small prolegs at both ends of the animal, rarely longer than 7mm.

outcome.name: Chironomid
outcome.habitat: All habitats. Common.
outcome.movement: : Coil and uncoil quickly in a figure of eight, sometimes thrashing or using prolegs to drag themselves along the ground.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive but quite variable.

questions.text: Head capsule retractable, no pro-legs, sometimes with a set of hairy, feathered or fleshy appendages at the posterior end, may be covered in downy hairs, often longer than 5mm.

outcome.name: Tipulidae
outcome.habitat: All habitats. Common but not abundant.
outcome.movement: Slow moving burrowing with twists, or with expansion and contraction.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive. Some have distinctive, swollen, rear ends (photo left) and others complicated breathing appendages (photo right).

questions.text: Animal without a head capsule; traditionally maggot-like in body form and movement.
Appendages along both sides of the animal (see picture).

outcome.name: Athericidae
outcome.habitat: Rivers, gravel and sand.
outcome.confusedWith: Nothing, very distinctive once you have definitely seen the side projections.

questions.text: Animal without appendages or only present on the final segments of the animal.

outcome.name: Tabanidae, Dolichopodidae, Empididae & some Tipulidae
outcome.habitat: Rivers, usually amongst gravels. Common.

questions.text: without hard mouthparts

outcome.name: Oligochaeta
outcome.habitat: Rivers, wetlands, in sediment.
outcome.movement: Like an earthworm. Smaller worms may swim by wriggling.
outcome.confusedWith: Leeches, but worms have no suckers.

questions.text: with suction cups on either end of the body
without a hardened head capsule

outcome.name: Hirudinea
outcome.habitat: Rivers, wetlands.
outcome.movement: Characteristic looping motion, elongation and contraction of body.
outcome.confusedWith: Worms or flatworms, neither of which have suckers.

outcome.habitat: Rivers, wetlands, all habitats in sediment.
